fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
By using git merge locally, you can effectively bypass the "Require Jira issue link" requirement on commits on a merge commit, if the parent commit has an issue key associated with it.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Enable the "Require Jira issue key" feature under the repository settings page > Links
 # Clone the repository locally
 # Create a new branch on the repository, and add a commit to it that has an issue key as normal.
 # Run git fetch on a local copy of the repository to fetch the newly created branch
 # Run git merge locally, and add a message that does *not* contain an issue key:
{code}
git merge --no-ff origin/myBranch -m "test"
{code}
If you try pushing at this point, Bitbucket should block the attempt. This does not happen, the push goes through normally.

h3. Expected Results
Pushing back to a repository that has the "Require Jira issue key" setting enabled should not allow git pushes to the repository in any occasion.

h3. Actual Results
Bitbucket allows merge commits created locally that do not have an issue key associated with them to be pushed to Bitbucket, effectively bypassing the "Require Jira issue key" requirement.

h3. Workaround
Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Local merge commit allows Jira link requirement to be bypassed

fields.description:
*Explanation*

Git has a feature to override the display email and name even in old commits. It's called the .mailmap file, and in recent versions of git it is enabled by default when viewing git log. This .mailmap file is useful for avoiding having to rewrite history in git when someone changes their name, such as when getting married, transitioning gender, or replacing their single-word glam name with "The Artist Formerly Known As GlamName".

 

*Suggestion*

In the main branch of a repo, if the latest commit has a .mailmap at the root, apply that in all display contexts.

 

*But there's an existing feature for this, isn't there?*

Each user in Bitbucket can set their alternative email addresses to correlate old commits with their active Atlassian account. Unfortunately, the user-level configuration for alternative email addresses requires that an email can be verified. It is often that old commits have "email addresses" that are computer names, or email addresses that belong to defunct domains, or just dead email addresses. Without .mailmap functionality, these display identities cannot be correlated with an active Atlassian user.
fields.summary: git .mailmap should be applied to user display names and emails

fields.description:
Hello, I would like to have the option to skip deploys in a certain environment group. Currently there are 3 in bitbucket: testing, staging, and production. Lets say I have 3 testing environments DEV1, DEV2, and DEV3, I have 2 staging environments STG1, STG2 and I have 2 production environments PROD1, PROD2. Now I can deploy to any of those environments if I set it up like so:
{code:java}
- parallel:          
    - step: *Deploy-dev1          
    - step: *Deploy-dev2
    - step: *Deploy-dev3
- parallel:          
    - step: *Deploy-stg1          
    - step: *Deploy-stg2
- parallel:          
    - step: *Deploy-prod1          
    - step: *Deploy-prod2
{code}
So I can click on the manual button for DEV1, DEV2, DEV3 and deploy to any of those environments, but I CANNOT deploy to STG1 or STG2 until I've deployed to ALL 3 DEV environments. Similarly, I cannot deploy to PROD1 or PROD2 until I've deployed to BOTH STG environments.

This doesn't really make sense. I'd like to be able to optionally deploy to any of my environments, but at the same time, skip some if desired.

The only way I've been able to make it work where I want to go say DEV2 -> STG2 -> PROD1 is by creating totally separate pipelines and then deploying via certain branches, but this is less than ideal.
fields.summary: Ability to Skip Deploys in Envrionment Group

fields.description:
I need to have an "optional: true/false" option available for steps. Imagine this scenario, where I have 5 DEV environments I can deploy to named DEV1, DEV2, DEV3, DEV4, DEV5. Right now, I'd set these up like so:
{code:java}
- parallel:          
    - step: *Deploy-dev1
    - step: *Deploy-dev2
    - step: *Deploy-dev3
    - step: *Deploy-dev4
    - step: *Deploy-dev5
{code}
This works if all 5 steps are manual steps. The problem is however, what if I only want to deploy to DEV3? My only option is to go DEV1, then DEV2, then DEV3. I can't just click the button for DEV3.

I would like the option to mark all 5 of those steps as optional, so I can click them in any order to deploy to my chosen environment.

Another scenario is the following. Say I have two DEV environments DEV1, DEV2, one STG environment STG1, and one PROD environment PROD1. You cannot do this:
{code:java}
- parallel:          
    - step: *Deploy-dev1
    - step: *Deploy-dev2
    - step: *Deploy-stg1
    - step: *Deploy-prod1{code}
Because bitbucket-pipelines will not allow you to mix DEV, STG, and PROD steps in a parallel group. I would really like the ability to set a step as optional or to be able to ignore a step and mark it as complete or some other similar functionality.
fields.summary: Optional Bitbucket Deploy Steps

fields.description:
h2. Summary

The default client version is currently Dockerv19 which is missing a feature that was in previous and newer versions.

Specifically, in versions prior to v19, you were able to omit a tag and the result was to push all tags, in v19 this default was changed to only push latest without providing an option/feature flag to then push to all. In v20, this [feature flag|https://github.com/docker/cli/pull/2220] now exists.
h2. Workaround

You can upgrade the client version of docker yourself by either using an appropriate image or by downloading and installing the newer version as a build step.

Example image with dockerv20 client
{code:java}
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        image: atlassian/pipelines-docker-daemon:v20-stable
        services:
        - docker
        script:
        - docker version
{code}
Example install of dockerv20 into any existing image (also works on default image)
{code:java}
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        services:
          - docker
        script:
          - curl -s -O https://download.docker.com/linux/static/stable/x86_64/docker-20.10.5.tgz
          - tar --extract --file=docker-20.10.5.tgz
          - ls -al ./docker
          - export PATH=./docker:$PATH
          - which docker
          - docker version
{code}
fields.summary: Bitbucket Pipelines: Upgrade Docker client default from v19 to v20

fields.description:
Currently pipelines containerisation does no allow ptrace() sys calls to be made, due to the seccomp restrictions.

There are work arounds, which involve using docker in docker to wrap whatever code/script needs to make ptrace calls.

To work around the problem, you can set up a step, using docker, and run the command(s) requiring ptrace. The docker in docker service allows SYS_PTRACE, and therefore ptrace(), however pipelines does not yet allow this outside of docker.

e.g

{code:java}
- step:
     services:
        - docker
     script:
        - docker run -v $(pwd):$(pwd) -w $(pwd) <yourimage> ./commands.sh
{code}

Is it possible to allow ptrace()  ? This will greatly assist anyone using certain debugging tools within pipelines. As an example, the below fails under pipelines:

{code:java}
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        image: ubuntu:18.04
        script:
          - apt-get update && apt-get install -y gcc
          - gcc -fsanitize=address my-app.c
          - LSAN_OPTIONS=verbosity=1:log_threads=1 ./a.out
{code}

Running the same set of commands inside of a docker run works:

{code:java}
pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        image: ubuntu:18.04
        services:
          - docker
        script:
          # contents of script.sh is the script block from the previous example.
          - docker run -v $(pwd):$(pwd) -w $(pwd) ubuntu:18.04 ./script.sh
{code}
fields.summary: Enable SYS_PTRACE capability for pipelines build environments

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
The PR:updated or PR:created webhooks truncate commit hashes instead of giving you the full commit hash.

This is a problem mainly with workflows that require git fetch to be executed - Git fetch requires the full commit hash, so this limitation actively breaks certain workflows

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a webhook that has PR:updated or PR:Created as its event
 # Trigger the PR:updated/PR:createdevent by updating a Pull request
 # You should be able to see that the payload truncates the commit SHA field to have only the first 12 characters of the commit SHA

h3. Expected Results
The complete commit SHA should be sent on the payload, like this:
{code}
[...]
{"commitId":"abc15321e9fa",
[...]
{code}

h3. Actual Results
Only the first 12 characters of the commit SHA are sent on the PR:Updated or PR:Created events:
{code}
[...]
{"commitId":"abc15321e9fa3485898703e88d3a72a6161adf4b",
[...]
{code}

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no way to work around this, in case you require the hook payload to run Git fetch. 
A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Pull request updated webhook payload has a different commit hash size than other webhooks

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
 * Some pull requests are displaying the diff command in the UI making it seem like there is additional content at the end of a file
 * But the lines are not present in the actual commits to the file
 * The issue is not consistent

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a pull request with changes
 # Review the diff for files with changes

h3. Expected Results

Nothing extra should be included in a pull request diff besides committed file content.
h3. Actual Results

Intermittently, the diff command is displayed appended at the end of a a file. 

For example, 
{code:java}
}diff --git a/file.txt b/file.txt{code}
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known consistent workaround for this behaviour. A workaround will be added here when available.
 * Disabling "Show: Whitespace changes" in your Pull Request settings may resolve the issue.
 * Pushing a new commit to your PR may resolve the issue.

PRs that are exhibiting this behaviour are safe to merge. The additional content will not be present in the resulting merge.
fields.summary: Pull request displaying diff command in the UI

fields.description:
At my company, multiple teams work on the same repository.  When creating a PR, the form is pre-filled with commonly-selected reviewers based on the repository.  Not everyone needs to know about all the PRs that go in, so I'd suggest that the list be based on a tuple of _the current user_ and _the repository_.

 

Some examples:
 * As a member of team A, a person A1 publishes a PR to repository R.  The list of reviewers includes other people on the team (A2, A3, A4).
 * As a member of team B, a person B2 publishes a PR to repository R.  The list of reviewers includes other people on the team (B1, B3).
 * As a new hire, a person C1 publishes a PR to repository R.  There is no history for this person, so default to either:
 ** common reviewers for the repository (as Bitbucket does now)
 ** all reviewers for the repository
fields.summary: When creating a PR, suggest reviewers based on the currently logged in user
